Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls
it back rapidly. Instead of being the most basic and obvious piece of design, scarcely
worth a moment’s notice, the seat promptly strikes him as deeply strange; the word ‘seat’ comes loose from its moorings,
the object it refers to shines forth in all its primordial oddity, as if he’s never
seen one before. Roquentin has to force himself to remember that this thing beside him is
something for people to sit on. For a terrifying moment, Roquentin has peered into what Sartre
calls the ‘absurdity of the world.’ Such a moment goes to the heart of Sartre’s
philosophy. To be Sartrean is to be aware of existence as it is when it has been stripped
of any of the prejudices and stabilising assumptions lent to us by our day-to-day routines. We can try out a Sartrean perspective on many
aspects of our own lives. Think of what you know as ‘the evening meal with your partner’. Under such a description, it all seems fairly
logical, but a Sartrean would strip away the surface normality to show the radical strangeness
lurking beneath. Dinner really means that:
when your part of the planet has spun away from the energy of a distant hydrogen and
helium explosion, you slide your knees under strips of a chopped-up
tree and put sections of dead animals and plants
in your mouth and chew, while next to you, another mammal whose genitals
you sometimes touch is doing the same. Two: We are free Such weird moments are certainly disorienting
and rather scary, but Sartre wants to draw our attention to them for one central reason:
because of their liberating dimensions. Life is a lot odder than we think, but it’s
also as a consequence far richer in possibilities. Things don’t have to be quite the way they
are. In the course of fully realising our freedom, we will come up against what Sartre calls the ‘angoisse’ or ‘anguish’ of existence.
Everything is (terrifyingly) possible because nothing has any pre-ordained, God-given sense
or purpose. Humans are just making it up as they go along,
and are free to cast aside the shackles at any moment. Three: We shouldn’t live in ‘Bad faith’ Sartre gave a term to the phenomenon of living
without taking freedom properly on board. He called it BAD FAITH. We are in bad faith whenever we tell ourselves
that things have to be a certain way and shut our eyes to other options. It is bad faith to insist that we have to
do a particular kind of work or live with a specific person or make our home in a given
place. The most famous description of ‘bad faith’
comes in Being and Nothingness, when Sartre notices a waiter who strikes him as overly
devoted to his role, as if he were first and foremost a waiter rather than a free human
being. His movement is quick and forward, a little
too precise, a little too rapid. He comes towards the patrons with a step that is a
little too quick. He bends forward a little too eagerly: his voice, his eyes express an
interest a little too solicitous for the order of the customer…’ The man (he was probably modelled on someone
in Saint-Germain’s Café de Flore) has convinced himself that he is essentially, necessarily
a waiter rather than a free creature who could be a jazz pianist or a fisherman on a North
Sea trawler. Four: We're free to dismantle capitalism. The one factor that most discourages people from experiencing themselves as free is money.
Most of us will shut down a range of possible options (moving abroad, trying out a new career,
leaving a partner) by saying,  ‘that’s if I didn’t have to worry about money.' This passivity in the face of money enraged
Sartre at a political level. He thought of capitalism as a giant machine designed to
create a sense of necessity which doesn’t in fact exist in reality: it makes us tell ourselves we have to work
a certain number of hours, buy a particular product or service, and so on. But in this, there is only the denial of freedom
– and a refusal to take as seriously as we should the possibility of living in other
ways. It was because of these views that Sartre
had a life long interest in Marxism. Marxism seemed in theory to allow people to explore
their freedom, by reducing the role played in their lives by material considerations. Sartre took part in many protests in the streets
of Paris in the 60s. Arrested yet again in 1968, President Charles de Gaulle had him
pardoned, saying, “you don’t arrest Voltaire.” Sartre also visited Fidel Castro and Che Guevara
and admired them both deeply. As a result of these connections and his radical politics,
the FBI kept a large file on Sartre trying to deduce what his suspicious philosophy might
really mean. Sartre is inspiring in his insistence that
things do not have to be the way they are. He is hugely alive to our unfulfilled potential,
as individuals and as a species. He urges us to accept the fluidity of existence and to create new institutions, habits, outlooks
and ideas. The admission that life doesn’t have some
preordained logic and is not inherently meaningful can be a source of immense relief when we
feel oppressed by the weight of tradition and the status quo.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: One of the ideas Sartre expresses in "Being and Nothingness" is that the world is _______ than we think.
Options: A. Weirder, B. Friendlier, C. Harder to see, D. Less important
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Jean-Paul Sartre born? Options: A. Berlin, B. Paris, C. Rome, D. London Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the title of Sartre's first novel, published in 1938? Options: A. Being and Nothingness, B. Nausea, C. Existentialism, D. The Absurdity of the World Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to Sartre, what happens when we experience the "absurdity of the world"? Options: A. We feel a sense of comfort and security, B. We realize that things are more logical than we thought, C. We see the world as it truly is, without our day-to-day assumptions, D. We become more confident in our understanding of the world Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the concept of "bad faith" in Sartre's philosophy? Options: A. Living without taking freedom properly on board and shutting our eyes to other options, B. Embracing our freedom and taking responsibility for our choices, C. Believing in a higher power or divine authority, D. Ignoring the absurdity of the world Correct Option: A
Question 5: How did Sartre think capitalism affects our sense of freedom? Options: A. It encourages us to explore our options and pursue our passions, B. It creates a sense of necessity that doesn't exist in reality, C. It has no impact on our sense of freedom, D. It helps us understand the absurdity of the world Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why did Sartre have a lifelong interest in Marxism? Options: A. Because it promoted individualism and capitalism, B. Because it seemed to allow people to explore their freedom by reducing material considerations, C. Because it was a popular ideology in France at the time, D. Because it aligned with his views on existentialism Correct Option: B
Question 7: Imagine you are a Sartrean philosopher. How would you describe the act of eating dinner with your partner? Options: A. As a romantic and intimate experience, B. As a necessary and mundane task, C. As a radical and strange act of consuming dead animals and plants, D. As a way to escape the absurdity of the world Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the relationship between Sartre's concept of freedom and the idea of "anguish"? Options: A. Freedom leads to a sense of security and comfort, B. Freedom leads to a sense of anguish and uncertainty, C. Anguish leads to a sense of freedom and empowerment, D. Anguish and freedom are unrelated concepts Correct Option: B
Question 9: How did Sartre's views on existentialism influence his politics? Options: A. He became a conservative and supported traditional institutions, B. He became a radical and supported revolutionary movements, C. He became apolitical and focused on individual freedom, D. He became a liberal and supported moderate reforms Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea behind Sartre's philosophy of existentialism? Options: A. That life has a predetermined meaning and purpose, B. That we must follow traditional norms and institutions, C. That we are free to create our own meaning and purpose in life, D. That the absurdity of the world is something to be feared and avoided Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

However, the options provided in Question 3 do not directly match the ground truth MCQ. A more accurate match in terms of question content would be:

**Question 7: Imagine you are a Sartrean philosopher. How would you describe the act of eating dinner with your partner?**

This question captures the idea of the world being "weirder" than we think, as described in the ground truth MCQ. However, the options provided in Question 7 do not directly match the ground truth MCQ.

A more accurate match in terms of question intent and options would be a combination of the content of Question 7 and the options of Question 3. However, since we need to choose one of the existing generated MCQs, I would recommend:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls
it back rapidly. Instead of being the most basic and obvious piece of design, scarcely
worth a moment’s notice, the seat promptly strikes him as deeply strange; the word ‘seat’ comes loose from its moorings,
the object it refers to shines forth in all its primordial oddity, as if he’s never
seen one before. Roquentin has to force himself to remember that this thing beside him is
something for people to sit on. For a terrifying moment, Roquentin has peered into what Sartre
calls the ‘absurdity of the world.’ Such a moment goes to the heart of Sartre’s
philosophy. To be Sartrean is to be aware of existence as it is when it has been stripped
of any of the prejudices and stabilising assumptions lent to us by our day-to-day routines. We can try out a Sartrean perspective on many
aspects of our own lives. Think of what you know as ‘the evening meal with your partner’. Under such a description, it all seems fairly
logical, but a Sartrean would strip away the surface normality to show the radical strangeness
lurking beneath. Dinner really means that:
when your part of the planet has spun away from the energy of a distant hydrogen and
helium explosion, you slide your knees under strips of a chopped-up
tree and put sections of dead animals and plants
in your mouth and chew, while next to you, another mammal whose genitals
you sometimes touch is doing the same. Two: We are free Such weird moments are certainly disorienting
and rather scary, but Sartre wants to draw our attention to them for one central reason:
because of their liberating dimensions. Life is a lot odder than we think, but it’s
also as a consequence far richer in possibilities. Things don’t have to be quite the way they
are. In the course of fully realising our freedom, we will come up against what Sartre calls the ‘angoisse’ or ‘anguish’ of existence.
Everything is (terrifyingly) possible because nothing has any pre-ordained, God-given sense
or purpose. Humans are just making it up as they go along,
and are free to cast aside the shackles at any moment. Three: We shouldn’t live in ‘Bad faith’ Sartre gave a term to the phenomenon of living
without taking freedom properly on board. He called it BAD FAITH. We are in bad faith whenever we tell ourselves
that things have to be a certain way and shut our eyes to other options. It is bad faith to insist that we have to
do a particular kind of work or live with a specific person or make our home in a given
place. The most famous description of ‘bad faith’
comes in Being and Nothingness, when Sartre notices a waiter who strikes him as overly
devoted to his role, as if he were first and foremost a waiter rather than a free human
being. His movement is quick and forward, a little
too precise, a little too rapid. He comes towards the patrons with a step that is a
little too quick. He bends forward a little too eagerly: his voice, his eyes express an
interest a little too solicitous for the order of the customer…’ The man (he was probably modelled on someone
in Saint-Germain’s Café de Flore) has convinced himself that he is essentially, necessarily
a waiter rather than a free creature who could be a jazz pianist or a fisherman on a North
Sea trawler. Four: We're free to dismantle capitalism. The one factor that most discourages people from experiencing themselves as free is money.
Most of us will shut down a range of possible options (moving abroad, trying out a new career,
leaving a partner) by saying,  ‘that’s if I didn’t have to worry about money.' This passivity in the face of money enraged
Sartre at a political level. He thought of capitalism as a giant machine designed to
create a sense of necessity which doesn’t in fact exist in reality: it makes us tell ourselves we have to work
a certain number of hours, buy a particular product or service, and so on. But in this, there is only the denial of freedom
– and a refusal to take as seriously as we should the possibility of living in other
ways. It was because of these views that Sartre
had a life long interest in Marxism. Marxism seemed in theory to allow people to explore
their freedom, by reducing the role played in their lives by material considerations. Sartre took part in many protests in the streets
of Paris in the 60s. Arrested yet again in 1968, President Charles de Gaulle had him
pardoned, saying, “you don’t arrest Voltaire.” Sartre also visited Fidel Castro and Che Guevara
and admired them both deeply. As a result of these connections and his radical politics,
the FBI kept a large file on Sartre trying to deduce what his suspicious philosophy might
really mean. Sartre is inspiring in his insistence that
things do not have to be the way they are. He is hugely alive to our unfulfilled potential,
as individuals and as a species. He urges us to accept the fluidity of existence and to create new institutions, habits, outlooks
and ideas. The admission that life doesn’t have some
preordained logic and is not inherently meaningful can be a source of immense relief when we
feel oppressed by the weight of tradition and the status quo.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is "bad faith?"
Options: A. Living without taking freedom properly on board; telling ourselves that things have to be a certain way, shutting our eyes to other options., B. Failing to worship a deity with the full piousness and devotion they deserve, C. Breaking promises to others frequently, thus creating a chain reaction of broken trust in society, D. Refusing to help others because of our belief that they deserve their bad conditions
Correct Option: A

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 4: What is the concept of "bad faith" in Sartre's philosophy?**

Options: A. Living without taking freedom properly on board and shutting our eyes to other options, B. Embracing our freedom and taking responsibility for our choices, C. Believing in a higher power or divine authority, D. Ignoring the absurdity of the world

Correct Option: A

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the concept of "bad faith" in Sartre's philosophy, and the correct option in both cases is the one that describes "bad faith" as living without taking freedom properly on board and shutting our eyes to other options.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls
it back rapidly. Instead of being the most basic and obvious piece of design, scarcely
worth a moment’s notice, the seat promptly strikes him as deeply strange; the word ‘seat’ comes loose from its moorings,
the object it refers to shines forth in all its primordial oddity, as if he’s never

calls the ‘absurdity of the world.’ Such a moment goes to the heart of Sartre’s
philosophy. To be Sartrean is to be aware of existence as it is when it has been stripped

aspects of our own lives. Think of what you know as ‘the evening meal with your partner’. Under such a description, it all seems fairly
logical, but a Sartrean would strip away the surface normality to show the radical strangeness
lurking beneath. Dinner really means that:
when your part of the planet has spun away from the energy of a distant hydrogen and

in your mouth and chew, while next to you, another mammal whose genitals

had a life long interest in Marxism. Marxism seemed in theory to allow people to explore
their freedom, by reducing the role played in their lives by material considerations. Sartre took part in many protests in the streets

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is "angoisse?"
Options: A. Anger, felt at the sense of our abandonment by God, B. Anguish, because everything is terrifyingly possible since nothing has pre-ordained meaning or purpose; humans are just making it up as we go along, C. Awe, due to the wondrous absurdity of everything around us and how incredible it is that everything works nevertheless, D. Apathy, created by our recognition that nothing matters
Correct Option: B

This question is similar in content and intent to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the definition of "angoisse." Both questions relate to the concept of anguish in Sartre's philosophy and its connection to human freedom. The correct options in both questions also convey the same idea: that anguish arises from the realization that everything is possible and that humans are free to choose their own path.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls
it back rapidly. Instead of being the most basic and obvious piece of design, scarcely
worth a moment’s notice, the seat promptly strikes him as deeply strange; the word ‘seat’ comes loose from its moorings,
the object it refers to shines forth in all its primordial oddity, as if he’s never
seen one before. Roquentin has to force himself to remember that this thing beside him is
something for people to sit on. For a terrifying moment, Roquentin has peered into what Sartre
calls the ‘absurdity of the world.’ Such a moment goes to the heart of Sartre’s
philosophy. To be Sartrean is to be aware of existence as it is when it has been stripped
of any of the prejudices and stabilising assumptions lent to us by our day-to-day routines. We can try out a Sartrean perspective on many
aspects of our own lives. Think of what you know as ‘the evening meal with your partner’. Under such a description, it all seems fairly
logical, but a Sartrean would strip away the surface normality to show the radical strangeness
lurking beneath. Dinner really means that:
when your part of the planet has spun away from the energy of a distant hydrogen and
helium explosion, you slide your knees under strips of a chopped-up
tree and put sections of dead animals and plants
in your mouth and chew, while next to you, another mammal whose genitals
you sometimes touch is doing the same. Two: We are free Such weird moments are certainly disorienting
and rather scary, but Sartre wants to draw our attention to them for one central reason:
because of their liberating dimensions. Life is a lot odder than we think, but it’s
also as a consequence far richer in possibilities. Things don’t have to be quite the way they
are. In the course of fully realising our freedom, we will come up against what Sartre calls the ‘angoisse’ or ‘anguish’ of existence.
Everything is (terrifyingly) possible because nothing has any pre-ordained, God-given sense
or purpose. Humans are just making it up as they go along,
and are free to cast aside the shackles at any moment. Three: We shouldn’t live in ‘Bad faith’ Sartre gave a term to the phenomenon of living
without taking freedom properly on board. He called it BAD FAITH. We are in bad faith whenever we tell ourselves
that things have to be a certain way and shut our eyes to other options. It is bad faith to insist that we have to
do a particular kind of work or live with a specific person or make our home in a given
place. The most famous description of ‘bad faith’
comes in Being and Nothingness, when Sartre notices a waiter who strikes him as overly
devoted to his role, as if he were first and foremost a waiter rather than a free human
being. His movement is quick and forward, a little
too precise, a little too rapid. He comes towards the patrons with a step that is a
little too quick. He bends forward a little too eagerly: his voice, his eyes express an
interest a little too solicitous for the order of the customer…’ The man (he was probably modelled on someone
in Saint-Germain’s Café de Flore) has convinced himself that he is essentially, necessarily
a waiter rather than a free creature who could be a jazz pianist or a fisherman on a North
Sea trawler. Four: We're free to dismantle capitalism. The one factor that most discourages people from experiencing themselves as free is money.
Most of us will shut down a range of possible options (moving abroad, trying out a new career,
leaving a partner) by saying,  ‘that’s if I didn’t have to worry about money.' This passivity in the face of money enraged
Sartre at a political level. He thought of capitalism as a giant machine designed to
create a sense of necessity which doesn’t in fact exist in reality: it makes us tell ourselves we have to work
a certain number of hours, buy a particular product or service, and so on. But in this, there is only the denial of freedom
– and a refusal to take as seriously as we should the possibility of living in other
ways. It was because of these views that Sartre
had a life long interest in Marxism. Marxism seemed in theory to allow people to explore
their freedom, by reducing the role played in their lives by material considerations. Sartre took part in many protests in the streets
of Paris in the 60s. Arrested yet again in 1968, President Charles de Gaulle had him
pardoned, saying, “you don’t arrest Voltaire.” Sartre also visited Fidel Castro and Che Guevara
and admired them both deeply. As a result of these connections and his radical politics,
the FBI kept a large file on Sartre trying to deduce what his suspicious philosophy might
really mean. Sartre is inspiring in his insistence that
things do not have to be the way they are. He is hugely alive to our unfulfilled potential,
as individuals and as a species. He urges us to accept the fluidity of existence and to create new institutions, habits, outlooks
and ideas. The admission that life doesn’t have some
preordained logic and is not inherently meaningful can be a source of immense relief when we
feel oppressed by the weight of tradition and the status quo.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do we see "the absurdity of the world?"
Options: A. Acknowledging what is important to us and what is not, B. Conducting ourselves in a humorous manner that implies we take little around us seriously, C. Being dutiful about worshipping whatever deities we believe in, D. Stripping away the prejudices and stabilizing assumptions lent to us by our day-to-day routines
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Jean-Paul Sartre born? Options: A. Berlin, B. Paris, C. Rome, D. London Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the title of Sartre's first novel, published in 1938? Options: A. Being and Nothingness, B. Nausea, C. Existentialism, D. The Absurdity of the World Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to Sartre, what happens when we experience the "absurdity of the world"? Options: A. We feel a sense of comfort and security, B. We realize that things are more logical than we thought, C. We see the world as it truly is, without our day-to-day assumptions, D. We become more confident in our understanding of the world Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the concept of "bad faith" in Sartre's philosophy? Options: A. Living without taking freedom properly on board and shutting our eyes to other options, B. Embracing our freedom and taking responsibility for our choices, C. Believing in a higher power or divine authority, D. Ignoring the absurdity of the world Correct Option: A
Question 5: How did Sartre think capitalism affects our sense of freedom? Options: A. It encourages us to explore our options and pursue our passions, B. It creates a sense of necessity that doesn't exist in reality, C. It has no impact on our sense of freedom, D. It helps us understand the absurdity of the world Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why did Sartre have a lifelong interest in Marxism? Options: A. Because it promoted individualism and capitalism, B. Because it seemed to allow people to explore their freedom by reducing material considerations, C. Because it was a popular ideology in France at the time, D. Because it aligned with his views on existentialism Correct Option: B
Question 7: Imagine you are a Sartrean philosopher. How would you describe the act of eating dinner with your partner? Options: A. As a romantic and intimate experience, B. As a necessary and mundane task, C. As a radical and strange act of consuming dead animals and plants, D. As a way to escape the absurdity of the world Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the relationship between Sartre's concept of freedom and the idea of "anguish"? Options: A. Freedom leads to a sense of security and comfort, B. Freedom leads to a sense of anguish and uncertainty, C. Anguish leads to a sense of freedom and empowerment, D. Anguish and freedom are unrelated concepts Correct Option: B
Question 9: How did Sartre's views on existentialism influence his politics? Options: A. He became a conservative and supported traditional institutions, B. He became a radical and supported revolutionary movements, C. He became apolitical and focused on individual freedom, D. He became a liberal and supported moderate reforms Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea behind Sartre's philosophy of existentialism? Options: A. That life has a predetermined meaning and purpose, B. That we must follow traditional norms and institutions, C. That we are free to create our own meaning and purpose in life, D. That the absurdity of the world is something to be feared and avoided Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 3: According to Sartre, what happens when we experience the "absurdity of the world"?**
Options: A. We feel a sense of comfort and security, B. We realize that things are more logical than we thought, C. We see the world as it truly is, without our day-to-day assumptions, D. We become more confident in our understanding of the world
Correct Option: C

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions are asking about how we experience the "absurdity of the world" according to Sartre's philosophy, and both correct options describe the idea of stripping away day-to-day assumptions to see the world as it truly is.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **3**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls
it back rapidly. Instead of being the most basic and obvious piece of design, scarcely
worth a moment’s notice, the seat promptly strikes him as deeply strange; the word ‘seat’ comes loose from its moorings,
the object it refers to shines forth in all its primordial oddity, as if he’s never
seen one before. Roquentin has to force himself to remember that this thing beside him is
something for people to sit on. For a terrifying moment, Roquentin has peered into what Sartre
calls the ‘absurdity of the world.’ Such a moment goes to the heart of Sartre’s
philosophy. To be Sartrean is to be aware of existence as it is when it has been stripped
of any of the prejudices and stabilising assumptions lent to us by our day-to-day routines. We can try out a Sartrean perspective on many
aspects of our own lives. Think of what you know as ‘the evening meal with your partner’. Under such a description, it all seems fairly
logical, but a Sartrean would strip away the surface normality to show the radical strangeness
lurking beneath. Dinner really means that:
when your part of the planet has spun away from the energy of a distant hydrogen and
helium explosion, you slide your knees under strips of a chopped-up
tree and put sections of dead animals and plants
in your mouth and chew, while next to you, another mammal whose genitals
you sometimes touch is doing the same. Two: We are free Such weird moments are certainly disorienting
and rather scary, but Sartre wants to draw our attention to them for one central reason:
because of their liberating dimensions. Life is a lot odder than we think, but it’s
also as a consequence far richer in possibilities. Things don’t have to be quite the way they
are. In the course of fully realising our freedom, we will come up against what Sartre calls the ‘angoisse’ or ‘anguish’ of existence.
Everything is (terrifyingly) possible because nothing has any pre-ordained, God-given sense
or purpose. Humans are just making it up as they go along,
and are free to cast aside the shackles at any moment. Three: We shouldn’t live in ‘Bad faith’ Sartre gave a term to the phenomenon of living
without taking freedom properly on board. He called it BAD FAITH. We are in bad faith whenever we tell ourselves
that things have to be a certain way and shut our eyes to other options. It is bad faith to insist that we have to
do a particular kind of work or live with a specific person or make our home in a given
place. The most famous description of ‘bad faith’
comes in Being and Nothingness, when Sartre notices a waiter who strikes him as overly
devoted to his role, as if he were first and foremost a waiter rather than a free human
being. His movement is quick and forward, a little
too precise, a little too rapid. He comes towards the patrons with a step that is a
little too quick. He bends forward a little too eagerly: his voice, his eyes express an
interest a little too solicitous for the order of the customer…’ The man (he was probably modelled on someone
in Saint-Germain’s Café de Flore) has convinced himself that he is essentially, necessarily
a waiter rather than a free creature who could be a jazz pianist or a fisherman on a North
Sea trawler. Four: We're free to dismantle capitalism. The one factor that most discourages people from experiencing themselves as free is money.

leaving a partner) by saying,  ‘that’s if I didn’t have to worry about money.' This passivity in the face of money enraged
Sartre at a political level. He thought of capitalism as a giant machine designed to
create a sense of necessity which doesn’t in fact exist in reality: it makes us tell ourselves we have to work
a certain number of hours, buy a particular product or service, and so on. But in this, there is only the denial of freedom
– and a refusal to take as seriously as we should the possibility of living in other
ways. It was because of these views that Sartre
had a life long interest in Marxism. Marxism seemed in theory to allow people to explore
their freedom, by reducing the role played in their lives by material considerations. Sartre took part in many protests in the streets
of Paris in the 60s. Arrested yet again in 1968, President Charles de Gaulle had him
pardoned, saying, “you don’t arrest Voltaire.” Sartre also visited Fidel Castro and Che Guevara
and admired them both deeply. As a result of these connections and his radical politics,
the FBI kept a large file on Sartre trying to deduce what his suspicious philosophy might
really mean. Sartre is inspiring in his insistence that
things do not have to be the way they are. He is hugely alive to our unfulfilled potential,
as individuals and as a species. He urges us to accept the fluidity of existence and to create new institutions, habits, outlooks
and ideas. The admission that life doesn’t have some
preordained logic and is not inherently meaningful can be a source of immense relief when we
feel oppressed by the weight of tradition and the status quo.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Nausea protagonist Roquentin is overwhelmed by the profound absurdity of which ordinary object?
Options: A. Pole, B. Wire, C. Seat, D. Window
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls
it back rapidly. Instead of being the most basic and obvious piece of design, scarcely
worth a moment’s notice, the seat promptly strikes him as deeply strange; the word ‘seat’ comes loose from its moorings,

logical, but a Sartrean would strip away the surface normality to show the radical strangeness
lurking beneath. Dinner really means that:

Question: Sartre asserted that the world is _______ than we think.
Options: A. Friendlier, B. More precious, C. Weirder, D. Flatter
Correct Option: C

**Index of the most similar generated MCQ:** 3 (Although this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the most similar in terms of content.)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 7
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls
it back rapidly. Instead of being the most basic and obvious piece of design, scarcely
worth a moment’s notice, the seat promptly strikes him as deeply strange; the word ‘seat’ comes loose from its moorings,
the object it refers to shines forth in all its primordial oddity, as if he’s never
seen one before. Roquentin has to force himself to remember that this thing beside him is
something for people to sit on. For a terrifying moment, Roquentin has peered into what Sartre
calls the ‘absurdity of the world.’ Such a moment goes to the heart of Sartre’s
philosophy. To be Sartrean is to be aware of existence as it is when it has been stripped
of any of the prejudices and stabilising assumptions lent to us by our day-to-day routines. We can try out a Sartrean perspective on many
aspects of our own lives. Think of what you know as ‘the evening meal with your partner’. Under such a description, it all seems fairly
logical, but a Sartrean would strip away the surface normality to show the radical strangeness
lurking beneath. Dinner really means that:
when your part of the planet has spun away from the energy of a distant hydrogen and
helium explosion, you slide your knees under strips of a chopped-up
tree and put sections of dead animals and plants
in your mouth and chew, while next to you, another mammal whose genitals
you sometimes touch is doing the same. Two: We are free Such weird moments are certainly disorienting
and rather scary, but Sartre wants to draw our attention to them for one central reason:
because of their liberating dimensions. Life is a lot odder than we think, but it’s
also as a consequence far richer in possibilities. Things don’t have to be quite the way they
are. In the course of fully realising our freedom, we will come up against what Sartre calls the ‘angoisse’ or ‘anguish’ of existence.
Everything is (terrifyingly) possible because nothing has any pre-ordained, God-given sense
or purpose. Humans are just making it up as they go along,
and are free to cast aside the shackles at any moment. Three: We shouldn’t live in ‘Bad faith’ Sartre gave a term to the phenomenon of living
without taking freedom properly on board. He called it BAD FAITH. We are in bad faith whenever we tell ourselves
that things have to be a certain way and shut our eyes to other options. It is bad faith to insist that we have to
do a particular kind of work or live with a specific person or make our home in a given
place. The most famous description of ‘bad faith’
comes in Being and Nothingness, when Sartre notices a waiter who strikes him as overly
devoted to his role, as if he were first and foremost a waiter rather than a free human
being. His movement is quick and forward, a little
too precise, a little too rapid. He comes towards the patrons with a step that is a
little too quick. He bends forward a little too eagerly: his voice, his eyes express an
interest a little too solicitous for the order of the customer…’ The man (he was probably modelled on someone
in Saint-Germain’s Café de Flore) has convinced himself that he is essentially, necessarily
a waiter rather than a free creature who could be a jazz pianist or a fisherman on a North
Sea trawler. Four: We're free to dismantle capitalism. The one factor that most discourages people from experiencing themselves as free is money.
Most of us will shut down a range of possible options (moving abroad, trying out a new career,
leaving a partner) by saying,  ‘that’s if I didn’t have to worry about money.' This passivity in the face of money enraged
Sartre at a political level. He thought of capitalism as a giant machine designed to
create a sense of necessity which doesn’t in fact exist in reality: it makes us tell ourselves we have to work
a certain number of hours, buy a particular product or service, and so on. But in this, there is only the denial of freedom
– and a refusal to take as seriously as we should the possibility of living in other
ways. It was because of these views that Sartre
had a life long interest in Marxism. Marxism seemed in theory to allow people to explore
their freedom, by reducing the role played in their lives by material considerations. Sartre took part in many protests in the streets
of Paris in the 60s. Arrested yet again in 1968, President Charles de Gaulle had him
pardoned, saying, “you don’t arrest Voltaire.” Sartre also visited Fidel Castro and Che Guevara
and admired them both deeply. As a result of these connections and his radical politics,
the FBI kept a large file on Sartre trying to deduce what his suspicious philosophy might
really mean. Sartre is inspiring in his insistence that
things do not have to be the way they are. He is hugely alive to our unfulfilled potential,
as individuals and as a species. He urges us to accept the fluidity of existence and to create new institutions, habits, outlooks
and ideas. The admission that life doesn’t have some
preordained logic and is not inherently meaningful can be a source of immense relief when we
feel oppressed by the weight of tradition and the status quo.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is bad faith?
Options: A. Pretending to have faith in a deity but not really believing, B. Frequently breaking promises made to others, leading to a loss of trust, C. Living without taking freedom properly on board, by telling ourselves that things have to be a certain way, D. Refusing to help others because we believe they deserve their conditions
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Jean-Paul Sartre born? Options: A. Berlin, B. Paris, C. Rome, D. London Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the title of Sartre's first novel, published in 1938? Options: A. Being and Nothingness, B. Nausea, C. Existentialism, D. The Absurdity of the World Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to Sartre, what happens when we experience the "absurdity of the world"? Options: A. We feel a sense of comfort and security, B. We realize that things are more logical than we thought, C. We see the world as it truly is, without our day-to-day assumptions, D. We become more confident in our understanding of the world Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the concept of "bad faith" in Sartre's philosophy? Options: A. Living without taking freedom properly on board and shutting our eyes to other options, B. Embracing our freedom and taking responsibility for our choices, C. Believing in a higher power or divine authority, D. Ignoring the absurdity of the world Correct Option: A
Question 5: How did Sartre think capitalism affects our sense of freedom? Options: A. It encourages us to explore our options and pursue our passions, B. It creates a sense of necessity that doesn't exist in reality, C. It has no impact on our sense of freedom, D. It helps us understand the absurdity of the world Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why did Sartre have a lifelong interest in Marxism? Options: A. Because it promoted individualism and capitalism, B. Because it seemed to allow people to explore their freedom by reducing material considerations, C. Because it was a popular ideology in France at the time, D. Because it aligned with his views on existentialism Correct Option: B
Question 7: Imagine you are a Sartrean philosopher. How would you describe the act of eating dinner with your partner? Options: A. As a romantic and intimate experience, B. As a necessary and mundane task, C. As a radical and strange act of consuming dead animals and plants, D. As a way to escape the absurdity of the world Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the relationship between Sartre's concept of freedom and the idea of "anguish"? Options: A. Freedom leads to a sense of security and comfort, B. Freedom leads to a sense of anguish and uncertainty, C. Anguish leads to a sense of freedom and empowerment, D. Anguish and freedom are unrelated concepts Correct Option: B
Question 9: How did Sartre's views on existentialism influence his politics? Options: A. He became a conservative and supported traditional institutions, B. He became a radical and supported revolutionary movements, C. He became apolitical and focused on individual freedom, D. He became a liberal and supported moderate reforms Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea behind Sartre's philosophy of existentialism? Options: A. That life has a predetermined meaning and purpose, B. That we must follow traditional norms and institutions, C. That we are free to create our own meaning and purpose in life, D. That the absurdity of the world is something to be feared and avoided Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 4: What is the concept of "bad faith" in Sartre's philosophy?**

Options: A. Living without taking freedom properly on board and shutting our eyes to other options, B. Embracing our freedom and taking responsibility for our choices, C. Believing in a higher power or divine authority, D. Ignoring the absurdity of the world

Correct Option: A

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the concept of "bad faith" in Sartre's philosophy, and the correct options are similar in meaning.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **4**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 8

glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 9
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of

Freedom leads to a sense of anguish and uncertainty, C. Anguish leads to a sense of freedom and empowerment, D. Anguish and freedom are unrelated concepts Correct Option: B

He became a radical and supported revolutionary movements, C. He became apolitical and focused on individual freedom, D. He became a liberal and supported moderate reforms Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea behind Sartre's philosophy of existentialism? Options: A. That life has a predetermined meaning and purpose, B. That we must follow traditional norms and institutions, C. That we are free to create our own meaning and purpose in life, D. That the absurdity of the world is something to be feared and avoided Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 2: What was the title of Sartre's first novel, published in 1938? Options: A. Being and Nothingness, B. Nausea, C. Existentialism, D. The Absurdity of the World Correct Option: B**

This question has the same intent and content as the ground truth MCQ, asking about the title of Sartre's first novel. The options are also similar, with the correct option being "Nausea" in both cases.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 10
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls
it back rapidly. Instead of being the most basic and obvious piece of design, scarcely
worth a moment’s notice, the seat promptly strikes him as deeply strange; the word ‘seat’ comes loose from its moorings,
the object it refers to shines forth in all its primordial oddity, as if he’s never
seen one before. Roquentin has to force himself to remember that this thing beside him is
something for people to sit on. For a terrifying moment, Roquentin has peered into what Sartre
calls the ‘absurdity of the world.’ Such a moment goes to the heart of Sartre’s
philosophy. To be Sartrean is to be aware of existence as it is when it has been stripped
of any of the prejudices and stabilising assumptions lent to us by our day-to-day routines. We can try out a Sartrean perspective on many
aspects of our own lives. Think of what you know as ‘the evening meal with your partner’. Under such a description, it all seems fairly
logical, but a Sartrean would strip away the surface normality to show the radical strangeness
lurking beneath. Dinner really means that:
when your part of the planet has spun away from the energy of a distant hydrogen and
helium explosion, you slide your knees under strips of a chopped-up
tree and put sections of dead animals and plants
in your mouth and chew, while next to you, another mammal whose genitals
you sometimes touch is doing the same. Two: We are free Such weird moments are certainly disorienting
and rather scary, but Sartre wants to draw our attention to them for one central reason:
because of their liberating dimensions. Life is a lot odder than we think, but it’s
also as a consequence far richer in possibilities. Things don’t have to be quite the way they
are. In the course of fully realising our freedom, we will come up against what Sartre calls the ‘angoisse’ or ‘anguish’ of existence.
Everything is (terrifyingly) possible because nothing has any pre-ordained, God-given sense
or purpose. Humans are just making it up as they go along,
and are free to cast aside the shackles at any moment. Three: We shouldn’t live in ‘Bad faith’ Sartre gave a term to the phenomenon of living
without taking freedom properly on board. He called it BAD FAITH. We are in bad faith whenever we tell ourselves
that things have to be a certain way and shut our eyes to other options. It is bad faith to insist that we have to
do a particular kind of work or live with a specific person or make our home in a given
place. The most famous description of ‘bad faith’
comes in Being and Nothingness, when Sartre notices a waiter who strikes him as overly
devoted to his role, as if he were first and foremost a waiter rather than a free human
being. His movement is quick and forward, a little
too precise, a little too rapid. He comes towards the patrons with a step that is a
little too quick. He bends forward a little too eagerly: his voice, his eyes express an
interest a little too solicitous for the order of the customer…’ The man (he was probably modelled on someone
in Saint-Germain’s Café de Flore) has convinced himself that he is essentially, necessarily
a waiter rather than a free creature who could be a jazz pianist or a fisherman on a North
Sea trawler. Four: We're free to dismantle capitalism. The one factor that most discourages people from experiencing themselves as free is money.
Most of us will shut down a range of possible options (moving abroad, trying out a new career,
leaving a partner) by saying,  ‘that’s if I didn’t have to worry about money.' This passivity in the face of money enraged
Sartre at a political level. He thought of capitalism as a giant machine designed to
create a sense of necessity which doesn’t in fact exist in reality: it makes us tell ourselves we have to work
a certain number of hours, buy a particular product or service, and so on. But in this, there is only the denial of freedom
– and a refusal to take as seriously as we should the possibility of living in other
ways. It was because of these views that Sartre
had a life long interest in Marxism. Marxism seemed in theory to allow people to explore
their freedom, by reducing the role played in their lives by material considerations. Sartre took part in many protests in the streets
of Paris in the 60s. Arrested yet again in 1968, President Charles de Gaulle had him
pardoned, saying, “you don’t arrest Voltaire.” Sartre also visited Fidel Castro and Che Guevara
and admired them both deeply. As a result of these connections and his radical politics,
the FBI kept a large file on Sartre trying to deduce what his suspicious philosophy might
really mean. Sartre is inspiring in his insistence that
things do not have to be the way they are. He is hugely alive to our unfulfilled potential,
as individuals and as a species. He urges us to accept the fluidity of existence and to create new institutions, habits, outlooks
and ideas. The admission that life doesn’t have some
preordained logic and is not inherently meaningful can be a source of immense relief when we
feel oppressed by the weight of tradition and the status quo.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Sartre's chosen philosophy was called...
Options: A. Nihilism, B. Cynicism, C. Hedonism, D. Existentialism
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Jean-Paul Sartre born? Options: A. Berlin, B. Paris, C. Rome, D. London Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the title of Sartre's first novel, published in 1938? Options: A. Being and Nothingness, B. Nausea, C. Existentialism, D. The Absurdity of the World Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to Sartre, what happens when we experience the "absurdity of the world"? Options: A. We feel a sense of comfort and security, B. We realize that things are more logical than we thought, C. We see the world as it truly is, without our day-to-day assumptions, D. We become more confident in our understanding of the world Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the concept of "bad faith" in Sartre's philosophy? Options: A. Living without taking freedom properly on board and shutting our eyes to other options, B. Embracing our freedom and taking responsibility for our choices, C. Believing in a higher power or divine authority, D. Ignoring the absurdity of the world Correct Option: A
Question 5: How did Sartre think capitalism affects our sense of freedom? Options: A. It encourages us to explore our options and pursue our passions, B. It creates a sense of necessity that doesn't exist in reality, C. It has no impact on our sense of freedom, D. It helps us understand the absurdity of the world Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why did Sartre have a lifelong interest in Marxism? Options: A. Because it promoted individualism and capitalism, B. Because it seemed to allow people to explore their freedom by reducing material considerations, C. Because it was a popular ideology in France at the time, D. Because it aligned with his views on existentialism Correct Option: B
Question 7: Imagine you are a Sartrean philosopher. How would you describe the act of eating dinner with your partner? Options: A. As a romantic and intimate experience, B. As a necessary and mundane task, C. As a radical and strange act of consuming dead animals and plants, D. As a way to escape the absurdity of the world Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the relationship between Sartre's concept of freedom and the idea of "anguish"? Options: A. Freedom leads to a sense of security and comfort, B. Freedom leads to a sense of anguish and uncertainty, C. Anguish leads to a sense of freedom and empowerment, D. Anguish and freedom are unrelated concepts Correct Option: B
Question 9: How did Sartre's views on existentialism influence his politics? Options: A. He became a conservative and supported traditional institutions, B. He became a radical and supported revolutionary movements, C. He became apolitical and focused on individual freedom, D. He became a liberal and supported moderate reforms Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea behind Sartre's philosophy of existentialism? Options: A. That life has a predetermined meaning and purpose, B. That we must follow traditional norms and institutions, C. That we are free to create our own meaning and purpose in life, D. That the absurdity of the world is something to be feared and avoided Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 10: What is the main idea behind Sartre's philosophy of existentialism?**

Options: A. That life has a predetermined meaning and purpose, B. That we must follow traditional norms and institutions, C. That we are free to create our own meaning and purpose in life, D. That the absurdity of the world is something to be feared and avoided

Correct Option: C

1. Asks about Sartre's philosophy (existentialism)
2. Provides options that are relevant to the topic
3. Has a correct option that aligns with the main idea of existentialism (freedom to create one's own meaning and purpose)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 11

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book

could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 12
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is "angoisse?"
Options: A. Anger, felt at the sense of our abandonment by God, B. Anguish, because everything is terrifyingly possible since nothing has pre-ordained meaning or purpose; humans are just making it up as we go along, C. Awe, due to the wondrous absurdity of everything around us and how incredible it is that everything works nevertheless, D. Apathy, created by our recognition that nothing matters
Correct Option: B
